questions.question_text: According to the best practices for mission critical devices, what is the recommended interval for antivirus updates?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Antivirus content update frequency should be set to hourly recurrence. This is the best practice to protect the firewall from latest know viruses. The action should be download and install to have the new contenet updates installed on the firewall and not just downloaded.
https://live.paloaltonetworks.com/t5/best-practice-assessment-device/dynamic-updates-antivirus/ta-p/338194

Selected Answer: C
C is correct.
Sorry I mean 24h for threshold

In my last cooment I made reference to this link

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-1/pan-os-upgrade/software-and-content-updates/best-practices-for-app-and-threat-content-updates/best-practices-mission-critical#id184AH00L078

This is a tricky question, because is asking about the recommended update interval which following Palo Alto recommendations is 30min to then set the threshold for up to 48h

Antivirus updates are released every 24 hours, a lower time recurrence ensures the FW is equipped with the latest updates.

according to this link PA recommends update interval of 30min and install threshold of 48h

Selected Answer: B
B recommended by PA so the FW can try again the same day in case of a failed update. Otherwise it would wait until the next day.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct.

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/11-1/pan-os-upgrade/software-and-content-updates/best-practices-for-app-and-threat-content-updates#id1791B0X06AS

According to the link. Mission critical approach doesn't like to update fast in order to not cause any down time with application changes.

B

Antivirus Antivirus updates are released every 24 hours and include:

Selected Answer: B
B
New antivirus signatures are published daily But the firewall can check for antivirus updates every hour.

comments.content:
@blackisok
Based on the link you provided this is incorrect. Decryption should be first as it is done in the Tunnel decapsulation of the the Ingress Stage. Zone Protection checks is done in the next Firewall Session Lookup Stage. Then Security Policy, then App-ID.
So based on your link it should be 
1. Decryption
2. Zone Protection
3. Security Profile
4. App-ID
i think this is it too. Security profile should come first before App-ID. If not what App-ID does it know to check if it does not see the profile first.

discussion.content:
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClVHCA0
1. Zone protection
2. Decryption
3. App-ID
4. Security profile enforcement

I believe that it goes in this order
1.Decryption
2.Zone protection
3.Security profile enforcement
4.App-ID

comments.content: This seems right to me. Not sure why people are saying Zone protection comes first. The Palo Alto doc says that it's 3.1 - after decryption.

discussion.content: IPSec/SSL tunnel decryption --> zone protection --> app-id(SSL/SSH) --> SSL/SSH proxy engine --> app-id --> security profile (content inspection )

The packet processing order in Palo Alto Networks firewalls typically follows these steps:

Packet Ingress:

Zone Protection: This is where the firewall evaluates if the packet complies with the security policies defined for the source and destination zones.
Decryption:

If the traffic is encrypted, the firewall decrypts the packet to inspect the decrypted content. Decryption is often performed using SSL decryption policies.
App-ID (Application Identification):

The firewall identifies the application associated with the traffic. This is a crucial step in allowing or blocking traffic based on the specific applications being used.
Security Profile Enforcement:

After the application is identified, security profiles (such as antivirus, anti-spyware, and vulnerability protection) are applied to the traffic to detect and prevent threats.

This question is confusing as f*ck.
It all depends on wether decryption is based on ssl proxy or VPN traffic
And wether a session already exists or not.

So if this would be adressing a NEW session of SSL Proxy traffic, the order should be
1. Zone protection
2. Decryption
3. App-ID
4. Security profile enforcement

Decryption
Zone protection
App-ID
Security profile enforcement

I think it should be Decryption, Zone Protection, App-ID then Security Profile enforcement. See link below.
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000ClVHCA0

1. Zone protection
2. Security profile enforcement
3. Decryption
4. App id

1. Zone protection
2. Decryption
3. App id
4. Security profile enforcement
https://networkinterview.com/packet-flow-in-palo-alto-detailed-explanation/

Zone Protection Checks
TCP State Check
Forwarding (based on interface type)
NAT Policy Lookup (only L3 & Virt wire)
DoS Protection Policy Lookup
Security Policy Lookup
Session Allocation
Firewall Session Fast Path (if packet from existing session)
Security Processing
Captive Portal
Application Identification
Content Inspection
Forwarding/Egress (includes QoS)

comments.content: Where would you say that decryption process is taking place?
I would say it would have to be taking place first or else the contents of the packet wouldnt be able to be read to determine the remaining Zone/Security/App info.

Addresses list?

discussion.content:

B.I think so too.Its nesesary source ip address.

Selected Answer: B
B, it identifies adresses.

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-0/pan-os-admin/policy/use-an-external-dynamic-list-in-policy/external-dynamic-list

Yes, you’re correctAuthentication policies can indeed use URL categories as match criteria12.

In Palo Alto’s PAN-OS, Authentication policies are used to authenticate end users before they can access services and applications12. When configuring an Authentication policy, you can ensure that your Security Policy allows users to access the services and URL categories that require authentication1.

Therefore, the correct answers are A. authentication and B. decryption.

Selected Answer: AB
There are many ways to enforce web page access beyond only blocking and allowing certain sites. For example, you can use multiple categories per URL to allow users to access a site, but block particular functions like submitting corporate credentials or downloading files. You can also use URL categories to enforce different types of policy, such as Authentication, Decryption, QoS, and Security.

Selected Answer: AB
The answers are correct. 

Source: https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/url-filtering/how-to-use-url-categories

questions.question_text: URL categories can be used as match criteria on which two policy types? (Choose two.)

Given the screenshot, what are two correct statements about the logged traffic? (Choose two.)
//IMG//

choices.B: The traffic was denied by security profile.
choices.C: The traffic was denied by URL filtering.
choices.A: The web session was unsuccessfully decrypted.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
Entries for traffic that matches the URL Filtering profile attached to a security policy rule- will show as url
Entries generated when traffic matches one of the Security Profiles attached to a security rule on the firewall- it will show as threat

The session was decrypted because you can see web-browsing over port 443 

The traffic was denied by a security profile https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA14u000000HCQlCAO

comments.content: How to read that it was decrypted? There are some 443 traffic not decrypted..

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
Answer D: SSL (443) + decrypt= web-browsing.

Answer B: URL filtering is a security profile
How can I read that the traffic was denied?

Selected Answer: BD
B and D are correct.
